Shooterandproud

Whats your opinion? Canon dslrs or Nikon dslrs? I personally like Nikon because their cameras feel a lot better in my hand, but I don't really know much about the advantages and disadvantages of each.
jim's trucking

Whats your opinion? Canon dslrs or Nikon dslrs? I personally like Nikon because their cameras feel a lot better in my hand, but I don't really know much about the advantages and disadvantages of each.
Both are high quality when you get to the high priced models.
 
 Let me confuse you a bit more by suggesting you add the upper-end Panasonic Lumix cameras to your list of candidates.
Shooterandproud

I'm not sure there are Lumix DSLRs. I'll have to look into it.
 
 
 EDIT: My Nikon D40 came today. So far, I love it! It was a good price, it has a great selection of lenses, and I love the way it feels. I'll get some pics up soon.
Peeling

There's not a lot to choose between them technically unless your needs are very specific, so feel/handling/intuitive controls will probably make the biggest difference to the shots you get. My wife has had a D70 for a while now and recently upgraded to a D300, which is an absolute monster.
 
 A handy rule of thumb when deciding how to spend your cash is to think of lenses as an investment and the body as disposable.

And yes, the D300 is a beast, however if I had that kind of money to spend, I would get a D80 with some nice glass. I just don't need the power of the D300.

 A commendable attitude :)
 
 My wife is a portrait photographer (mostly children) and gets a lot of mileage out of the dynamic range, metering, high iso quality, autofocus and framerate, all of which help her nail the candid at home / playing in the garden shots that are her speciality. Shutter longevity is also an issue when you're taking upwards of 1000 pictures in an active hour-long shoot.
